column1: Rancho Cucamonga () is a city located just south of the foothills of the San Gabriel Mountains and Angeles National Forest in San Bernardino County
column2: California
column3: United States. About 37 miles (60 km) east of Downtown Los Angeles
column4: Rancho Cucamonga is the 26th most populous city in California. The city's seal
column5: which centers on a cluster of grapes
column6: alludes to the city's agricultural history including wine-making. The city's proximity to major transportation hubs
column8: and highways has attracted the business of several large corporations

column17: compared to a national average of 205 days. Its climate is classified as warm Mediterranean

column24: and Rancho Cucamonga) earned the Silver distinction in a 2015 ranking of the nation's high schools by U.S. News & World Report. In 2017 the California Department of Education announced that all four high schools were being named California Gold Ribbon Schools.The Jack Benny Program popularized the city's name

column2: Kukamongan Native Americans had established a village settlement in the area around present-day Red Hill
column3: near the city's western border. Kukamonga derives its name from a Tongva word meaning "sandy place." Anthropologists have determined that this cluster of settlers likely belonged to the Tongva people or Kich people
column4: at one time one of the largest concentrations of Native American peoples on the North American continent. In the 18th century
column5: following an expedition led by Gaspar de Portola
column6: the land was incorporated into the Mission System  established by Father Junipero Serra and his group of soldiers and Franciscan friars.

column12: irrigation tunnels were dug into Cucamonga Canyon by Chinese laborers and the Santa Fe Railroad was extended through the area. Among the town's economic mainstays was agriculture
column19: the Pacific Electric Railway was extended through Rancho Cucamonga in an effort to improve crop transportation. Several landmarks in existence today pay tribute to the city's multicultural founding. In particular

column2: first settled in 1869
column3: lay roughly between today's Victoria Groves Park and Central Park. There was a schoolhouse which also doubled as a church. In 1890 an irrigation district was formed and $200

column6: because the bond issue was declared illegal. "Orchards and vineyards began to die

column9: when the Fontana Union Water Company filled it with 5 million gallons of water. The local school district was merged with the Etiwanda district in 1901. In 1957 the settlement was practically deserted
column10: but there were still rabbit-proof stone walls marking boundaries of previous citrus orchards.

column1: Rancho Cucamonga is part of the Inland Empire and San Bernardino County
column2: a region that lies inland from the Pacific coast and directly east of Los Angeles County. Rancho Cucamonga is located about 37 miles (60 km) east of Los Angeles
column3: bordered by Upland to its west
column4: Ontario to its south
column5: the San Gabriel Mountains to its north and I-15 and Fontana to its east. The city sits atop an alluvial plain and views of Cucamonga Peak
column6: one of the tallest peaks of the San Gabriel Mountains
column7: are available from all points throughout the city. The city has a total area of 39.9 square miles (103 km2)
column8: 99.95% of which is land and 0.05% water.

column1: Victoria Gardens is a lifestyle center near the eastern end of the city
column2: at the intersection of Foothill and Day Creek Boulevards. Since the city had never developed a traditional commercial downtown like neighboring cities Ontario and Upland had
column3: efforts were made in the design of Victoria Gardens to bring elements of more traditional and urban town design to what had historically been a suburban city. While retaining many characteristics of traditional shopping malls
column4: such as large anchor stores
column6: and vast parking lots and garages
column7: the smaller stores are arranged as city blocks in a grid of two-lane streets
column8: featuring lush landscaping and metered "teaser parking" in front of the stores
column9: which open onto the sidewalk. There are two "Main Streets"
column10: which run from west to east across the center. Running from north to south between them is a pedestrian axis leading from one of the Macy's anchor stores
column11: through a "town square" between a pair of mixed-use office buildings
column12: to the Victoria Gardens Cultural Center
column13: which contains the Lewis Playhouse (a 570-seat theater) and a branch of the city library. The east side of the development has Southern California's only Bass Pro Shops Outdoor World superstore; the 180

column1: Rancho Cucamonga is a General Law City
column2: incorporated in 1977 under the "Council-Manager" form of local government. The four-member Council
column3: plus the Mayor
column4: City Clerk
column6: are all elected at-large by the voters of the city. The Council then appoints the City Manager
column7: who acts as the administrative head of the city government
column8: and is responsible for the day-to-day operations
column10: and the fiscal soundness of the municipal government. The council itself serves as a local legislative body.

column1: The city of Rancho Cucamonga has two public libraries
column2: with a combined total of over 200
column3: 000 volumes. The library at 7368 Archibald Avenue opened in 1994 and was remodeled in the summer of 2008. The Paul A. Biane library at 12505 Cultural Center Drive at the Victoria Gardens Cultural Center opened in August 2006. In 2013
column4: the Rancho Cucamonga Public Library was a recipient of the National Medal for Museum and Library Services
column5: the nation's highest honor that can be bestowed on a Library or Museum.

column1: Rancho Cucamonga's location at the base of the San Gabriel Mountains has necessitated the use of numerous control channels and basins to reduce the seasonal flood danger from the several streams descending from the range. In past years
column2: some of the city's roads were known for flooding. Hermosa Avenue
column3: in particular
column4: now features many high curbs and extra-large storm drain grates to reduce flooding.

column1: Rancho Cucamonga is served by Omnitrans bus service
column2: train service from Metrolink's Rancho Cucamonga station on the San Bernardino Line
column3: and nearby Ontario International Airport
column4: one of four major Los Angeles-area passenger airports with multiple daily flights by most domestic carriers as well as a major shipping hub for companies like UPS and FedEx.

column1: Interstate 15 (I-15) and the relatively new Route 210 (SR-210) freeway extension run through Rancho Cucamonga as well as the historic U.S. Route 66 (as Foothill Boulevard).
I-15 sits atop an elevated berm
column2: and cuts a curve through the southeastern part of the city
column3: isolating a mostly industrial area
column4: a small shopping center
column5: and several housing tracts from the larger part of the city. Further north
column6: I-15 forms part of the northeastern border with neighboring Fontana before entering the Cajon Pass through the San Gabriel Mountains. I-15 provides connectivity with the High Desert
column8: and points north for the Inland Empire and much of Southern California.

column1: SR-210 runs nearly straight east–west through the northern part of the city
column2: roughly bisecting the residential communities of Alta Loma and Etiwanda
column3: providing connection (in addition to I-10 and SR-60) from the San Gabriel Valley and points west to the San Bernardino area.

column1: Rancho Cucamonga receives natural gas from the Southern California Gas Company. The city's water supply and sewage are managed by the Cucamonga Valley Water District. Garbage collection is by Burrtec Disposal
column2: phone service is from Frontier Communications and cable TV is provided by Charter Communications.Electric power in Rancho Cucamonga is provided by Southern California Edison and the Rancho Cucamonga Municipal Utility

column4: on Etiwanda Avenue. This facility
column5: one of five Reliant stations in California
column6: is a natural gas-fired power plant
column7: which began operation in 1963. At 640 megawatts (860
column9: it is Reliant's second-highest capacity plant on the West Coast. It utilizes four steam turbine generators; of which units three and four remained active after turbines one and two
column10: as well as a combustion turbine
column12: respectively. Several systems are in place to control gas emissions
column18: 000 imp gal; 3.4 GL) of recycled water are used for cooling.On November 29

column1: The name "Cucamonga" became well known to fans of Jack Benny's popular radio program
column2: in which an announcer
column3: voiced by Mel Blanc
column4: would call out: "Train leaving on track five for Anaheim
column5: Azusa and Cu-camonga!" This running gag became so well known that it eventually led to a statue of Benny in Cucamonga.The city is also the primary setting of the show Workaholics.
